newsitem.title: SIERRA LEONE: Sierra Leone, Liberia agree extra border security.
newsitem.headline: Sierra Leone, Liberia agree extra border security.

text.p: The governments of Sierra Leone and Liberia have agreed to tighten security along their common border to prevent subversive elements crossing in either direction.

Sierra Leone President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah and the head of Liberia's interim ruling state council, Ruth Perry, said in a joint statment on Tuesday that a joint commission and mutual defence pact should be revived.

They made a joint call for Sierra Leone's rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, currently in Ivory Coast, to cooperate fully with the U.N. and other mediators and ensure early deployment of a peacekeeping mission under an Ivorian-mediated peace deal.

"The two heads of state underscored the need to reactivate as soon as possible the work of the joint commission of cooperation between both countries and their mutual defence pact," the joint statement said.

Tejan Kabbah took office in the former British colony in March 1996 after multi-party elections ended four years of army rule. He and Sankoh, who took up arms in 1991, signed a peace deal in Ivory Coast in November but implementation has dragged.
Liberia, set up by freed American slaves in 1847, is on course for May 30 elections to end seven years of civil war following disarmament that ended early in February.
